data.title: Jean Luc Dehaene
data.meta_description: Known to friends as “the plumber” but to foes as the “bulldozer” — both because of his uncanny ability to fix a deal — the Belgian prime minister Jean-Luc Dehaene was at the epicentre of every
data.text:
Known to friends as “the plumber” but to foes as the “bulldozer” — both because of his uncanny ability to fix a deal — the Belgian prime minister Jean-Luc Dehaene was at the epicentre of every European summit and spat of the 1990s.

Although cast on the EU stage as the beer-loving “Buddha in a suit”, Dehaene was a highly effective politician who steered Europe through the Maastricht treaty before he was brought down by a series of scandals at home.

For a short spell in the mid-1990s, Dehaene was also enemy No 1 of the British right. The odds-on favourite to succeed Jacques Delors as the president of the European Commission, Dehaene was considered too much of a federalist by John Major’s government.
